sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a combustion reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions (25°C and 1 atm pressure)? Given that the balanced equation for the reaction is:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation are: 

ΔHf°(CH4) = -74.8 kJ/mol,
ΔHf°(CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol,
ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

Express your answer in kJ/mol of CH4.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4), we can use the following equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ [ΔHf°(products)] - Σ [ΔHf°(reactants)]

For the given reaction:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation are:

ΔHf°(CH4) = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

We can plug these values into the equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = [1 × (-393.5) + 2 × (-285.8)] - [1 × (-74.8) + 2 × 0]

Note that the standard enthalpy of formation for O2 is 0 kJ/mol, as it is an element in its standard state.

ΔH°(reaction) = (-393.5 - 571.6) - (-74.8)
ΔH°(reaction) = -965.1 + 74.8
ΔH°(reaction) = -890.3 kJ/mol

Therefore, the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions (25°C and 1 atm pressure) is -890.3 kJ/mol of CH4.
